Posts.Content: Nov 29, 2007 09:12PM bomber410 wrote: Sheila, I just want to suggest something to you.  Instead of hiring the kids from your church, why not attach a little pusher shovel thing to your dog's nose.  He/she could push the leaves into a big pile.  Although I guess he/she'd be better for snow pushing.  Very cute doggie! As for triggering lymphedema, mine was drugs - taxotere.  But also I think I was prone to lymph. because of my vascular make up.  I don't have any kind of heart problem and am a very active runner.  However, even prior to BC, I noted that on greater than marathon distance runs, my lymphatic system couldn't keep up with the fluid moving through my body.  Following my first ultra distance run, I had a form of lymphedema (unknown to me at the time).  And it rest right in the forearm where the greatest build up is right now with this bout I'm in therapy for.  My girlfriend, 20 year survivor, double mast. etc, distance runner, very active inside and outside the house has never, ever had a problem.  Because of my early experience, I was watchful from the beginning and not surprised at this onset.  But at least it is now a known for me rather than a surprise a few years down the road.  I think the best thing has been this board and my LE therapist.  We're lucky to have lots of smart ladies like Binney around to help us adapt and continue on with relatively normal lives.  In fact, my LE therapist encourages me to run while my arm is in the bandages during this therapy period.  I don't have to stop doing everything I love.  Same is true for others.   We're all establishing the new normal. Debbie

Posts.Content: Oct 31, 2007 11:54AM bomber410 wrote: Hi Joanne,  I didn't realize some don't get boosts.  I guess I've read reference to them on the rad boards often enough to assume they are a given.  It'll be interesting to see what others have to say. Lymphedema is swelling, usually in the arms or legs, that occurs as a result of  an impaired lymphatic system.  For those of us with BC it is from the removal of lymph nodes with the sentinel node biopsy but more so with the axillary node dissection.  If the lymphatic system has been impaired, the lymph fluid can back up and swelling occurs.  It is an accumulation of tissue proteins, edema and chronic inflammation within an extremity. I was doing okay until the last month of chemo.  I think the edema from the taxotere that the steroids were to help abate may have contributed.  Radiation can also contribute to it. Some folks get truncal swelling as well as in the hands and arms.   The Lymphedema board here on bc.org has been a real help. Let me know if you want more information. Debbie

Posts.Content: Nov 5, 2007 05:05AM bomber410 wrote: Happy Monday ladies!  I trust we all had a recoverable weekend.  It was splendid here in New England.  On Saturday, we were supposed to get a Nor'easter as remnants of Noel.  Cape Cod got hit but not so much us on the North shore of Boston.  Too bad because I love a good storm.  It did rain so my SO and I drove down to Hartford CT to check out the new Cabela's.  What a place!  Sunday was a perfect fall day.  I got lots of yard work done.  As for radiation, since I guess that's why we're all here, I have 4 weeks of treatments under  my belt.  I do have skin breakage under my boob at the fold where the boob meets the rib cage.  I think it is a combination of the fragility of the skin and the abrasion of my running bra.  Regardless, I was given a prescription for Silvadene, a topical antibiotic. I also had a bit of a scare that was resolved on Friday.  I have a sore rib that isn't in the radiation field but on that side of my body.  I tried to connect with the onc. on Thursday afternoon but he was doing the breast clinic.  My regular rad appt is 4 PM.  I made plans to go in for my treatment a bit early on Friday to meet with the onc.  He sent me up for x-rays immediately. By the time I got back downstairs to radiation and changed, the onc was reviewing the x-rays on his computer.  He called me in to tell me he could see nothing to indicate mets.  Looks like I have an inflamed interstitial muscle.  Needless to say, I was greatly relieved.  Like he said, he didn't want me to worry about it the entire weekend.   Hope you all had a great weekend. Debbie

Posts.Content: Jun 25, 2008 05:31AM bomber410 wrote: I was on taxotere.  The edema didn't set in until the 3rd or 4th treatment of taxotere.  I can't remember exactly when.  It was back in late August/early September 2007.  Along with the overall edema it did trigger lymphedema in my right arm and breast. Over the next few months, each time I'd see a friend who I hadn't seen in a while, they'd note how much better I looked, how my face was slimming down.  It did take close to four months to get the edema to move out of my body.  I didn't take any medication.  Not one for taking extra stuff when all that's needed is to get this stuff out of one's body.  That takes time.   However, a residual effect of the overall edema is the triggering of the lymphedema.  I have been treated by a trained lymphedema specialist.  I do have both day and night sleeves and do self massage.  Overall, I'm back except for the LE.  That is getting better, as well. Good luck, Debbie

Posts.Title: Is Downhill Skiing a risk? PLilly Munchy

Posts.Content: Dec 18, 2007 05:23PM bomber410 wrote: As I understand it, your main concern is shared by both downhill and cross country.  You want to watch any finger/fist clenching.  If you have a sleeve, it may be good to wear for any activity that gets your heart to pumping and your fluids a' flowin'.  Even before BC, for any long distance activity, e.g. running, my hands would get puffy.  I knew i was prone to LE once i got BC.  But keep in mind, exercise is good for helping with the symptoms.  You just don't want the fluid to settle in your hand or lower arm.  Also with any exercise, watch your breathing and let yourself do good belly breathing to stimulate the thoracic duct. Enjoy! Debbie
Posts.Title: Is Downhill Skiing a risk? PLilly Munchy

Posts.Content: May 29, 2008 05:46AM bomber410 wrote: I have it and could have told you ahead of time I would get it because of my inefficient lymphatic system.  I've seen it in action pre-BC through my long distance running.  The fluid would back up and my hands would swell.  If I ran long distance with my fists clenched (you don't know you are doing it), it would cause the fluid to pool in my forearm.  That being said, I have a friend who is a 20 year survivor, radical mast, lots of nodes removed, distance runner as well.  No problem.  No LE.   The data shows the incidence is high.  However, it is not a sure thing you will get it.  Of course, there are things one can do to reduce the likelihood of bringing on an incidence of LE.  Other threads cover that topic. Posts.Content: Nov 27, 2007 07:00AM bomber410 wrote: One more thing to consider.  There was talk about wearing a compression chamisole for truncal lymphedema.  One of the gals on this board suggested a brand of lycra chamisoles.  One brand here in the states is Hanes and the Barely There line.  It is very cost effective.  It may help with your discomfort at least with your shoulders and torso.  The day before yesterday I wore a regular bra with thin straps, but not for the entire day.  I went to bed that night with no bra or chamisole and my LE therapist noted more swelling in the trunk the next morning (7AM appointment).  Yesterday and last night I wore one of the lycra chamisoles like I had been doing for the past few weeks and she noted the swelling was back down. They seem to provide just enough compression for me. Just one more thing to consider in our growing bag of tricks. Debbie

Posts.Content: Oct 8, 2007 02:07PM - edited Oct 8, 2007 02:07PM by bomber410 Hi Binney,  thanks for the information.  I had a right breast lumpectomy, sentinel node biopsy and right axillary dissection with 10 nodes removed.  Given that, I can work with the self-massage the book describes.  I certainly want to get this under control as I am a distance runner and know how the lymph nodes can be heavily taxed under marathon/ultramarathon conditions.  I am holding to my plan of returning to my life as it was before BC surgery.  Hence, my proactive lymphedema baseline early on.   I've been a voyeur on the lymphedema discussions for the last several months and learned so much from all of you.   I do not have the glove yet but was given the sleeve at that first appointment with the LE clinic.  I was only wearing the sleeve when I exercised and not during the course of a normal day.  Now it seems I should be wearing it daily.  I was also shown the arm exercises that first appt.  However, I've learned from the book that now that my arm is swollen, first I have to massage all the other areas before the arm in order to open up to accept the lymphatic fluid coming from the arm or it will cause more back up.   Does all this sound like I'm getting it right? Posts.Content: bomber410 wrote: Someone in a previous post mentioned taking Ibuprofen which is triggering this thread.  What have others heard about Ibuprofen being add odds with LE?  I ask because I get medical alerts such as the following through the Health Management Center my company offers through WebMD. Potential Drug-Condition Interaction: Ibuprofen 200 mg Oral Tablet and Lymphedema. According to your health record, you currently have 'Lymphedema'. Ibuprofen 200 mg Oral Tablet should be carefully evaluated in individuals with Lymphedema, a condition related to Disease of Cardiovascular System. Medication: Ibuprofen 200 mg Oral Tablet Condition: Lymphedema Priority. Call your doctor's office within the next week. Potential Drug-Condition Interaction: Ibuprofen 200 mg Oral Tablet and Swelling of the Lymph Nodes following Surgical Removal of the Breast. According to your health record, you currently have 'Swelling of the Lymph Nodes following Surgical Removal of the Breast'. Ibuprofen 200 mg Oral Tablet should be carefully evaluated in individuals with Swelling of the Lymph Nodes following Surgical Removal of the Breast, a condition related to Disease of Cardiovascular System. Medication: Ibuprofen 200 mg Oral Tablet Condition: Swelling of the Lymph Nodes following Surgical Removal of the Breast Priority. Call your doctor's office within the next week. Of course, I didn't call my doctor's office.  I just stopped taking Ibuprofen for all my aches and pains.  Use it very sparingly.  Does this concur with others' research? Posts.Content: Jun 16, 2010 01:09PM bomber410 wrote: I have LE brought on by chemo three years ago.  I do a fair amount of backpacking (35+lbs) for multi-day overnight hikes and daypacking for up to 8 hours in the mountains.  I cannot say that the backpacking/daypacking is making my LE any worse.  It can be a matter of how long you wear the pack without removing it, insuring you select a good pack with straps that help to displace the weight.  A good pack is designed actually to carry the weight in the lower region of the torso rather than high up on the shoulders. My two cents.

Posts.Content: Mar 3, 2008 10:38AM bomber410 wrote: I asked for the conscious sedation and they honored my request even though it meant more in hospital recovery time.  To me it was worth it.  I was told they would create a new incision.  I whined enough about 'yet another scar' and was surprised they used the same incision as the original port.  No new scar. Since it involves a stitch or two, I was to follow the requisite 48 hours before getting that area wet.   I also chose to stay out of the hot tub for a couple weeks (my choice) to minimize risk of infection. All in all, it was very uneventful.  I was back to running and other exercise within a couple days.   Debbie

Posts.Content: Jan 7, 2009 10:38AM bomber410 wrote: Hi Karen, I'm jumping in here.  I was on taxotere and definitely had very sore muscles and joints for several months after.  I finished chemo Sept 2007.  I can say that now I don't have any of that soreness.  It would ache when I got out of bed or stepped away from my desk. As for swollen hands, I believe taxotere did trigger my lymphedema.  It was initially swollen hand with no visible knuckles along with swollen arm and torso.  I went to a specialist (see LE group).  Got the hand under control and improvement in arm/torso, but LE is still there.  For the overall fluid type weight gain, it took a good 16 weeks to get my face, etc. back to normal.  Hang in there.  I was told I would start to feel like my old self 1 year post treatment (surgery/chemo/rads) and it's proving true. Posts.Content: Jun 2, 2009 07:23PM bomber410 wrote: mjones, you know your body best, especially have nearly 30 years post treatment (woo hoo!).  I am one of those who allows the ebb and flow of stable then puffy then do what's needed to stabilize again.  I would be in the camp that says go without the garment.  When you notice the puffiness and swelliing, do what you need to do to get it under control.  For me, sometimes it is enough to wear the night garment to stabilize.  I was in the hot tub last night and then did some very strenuous exericize in heat this evening.  I can feel the added puffiness.  I won't go back in the hot tub tonight and I may put on the night garment for bed.  Things get back to my normal which still means I have one arm bigger than the other but it is what it is.  I hope I'm making sense.  Bottom line, you'll know best.   Good luck!  76! Nice!

Posts.Content: May 22, 2008 10:34AM bomber410 wrote: I thought I responded to this one already.  I say 'Yes'.  I had the two node surgeries - sentinel node biopsy and complete axillary.  10 nodes removed.  I had the 4 ACs during which I kept hiking, running, biking, etc.  I had my first of 4 Taxoteres after which I did the Komen BC 3-day 60 miles in 90+F temperatures.  No problem up to this point.  Sometime around the 3rd/4th Taxotere, my knuckles disappeared, arm swollen, truncal swelling.  I've been dealing with LE ever since.  I did also have the radiation treatment but radiation is not what triggered LE.  I know it doesn't help.  :-) Hang in there.  There is some ease to the LE once the edema from the Taxotere lessens over the few months following completion of treatment.  LE didn't go away for me but did ease some.  Debbie
